content:
I completely agree! The cinematography and score were masterfully done. The way the camera captured the women's conversations and interactions was so nuanced and sensitive, it really added to the film's emotional impact. The use of close-ups, medium shots, and long takes created a sense of intimacy and immediacy, making you feel like you were part of the conversation.

And the score was indeed subtle yet powerful. Hildur Guðnadóttir's composition was perfect for the film, adding depth and emotion to the scenes without overpowering them. The way the music swelled during the more tense moments was breathtaking, and it really added to the overall emotional resonance of the film.

I think one of the things that makes "Women Talking" so effective is its ability to balance the intimate, character-driven moments with the larger themes and ideas. The film never feels too small or too big, and the cinematography and score play a huge role in achieving that balance.

It's great to hear that you felt like you were holding your breath during some of the more tense scenes! That's a testament to the film's ability to engage and emotional resonate with audiences.

What did you think of the performances from the ensemble cast? The chemistry between the actresses was incredible, and they all brought so much depth and nuance to their characters.
